In case you want to build a trap to catch food critics, the most effective bait by far would be a menu item that nobody else in their right mind would order. Spicy sushi pizza? Sniff. Sniff, sniff. Snap!
At least that's how it worked for me when I ate at Natsumi, a new lounge and restaurant that subjects sushi to permutations that defy national boundaries, not to mention simple logic.

Natsumi bears a look if only because it traffics in Japanese-Italian fusion, which promises to be one of the stranger subplots in New York dining this year. It opened around the same time as Dieci, in the East Village, where a Japanese chef is cooking lamb Bolognese and saucing steak with a wasabi-fortified veal reduction. Elsewhere, a two-level restaurant is rumored to be in the works with sushi on the first floor and pasta above. So I went to Natsumi to look, sniff, taste and scratch my head.

A bursting-at-the-seams salmon roll was peculiarly outfitted with chips of an Asiago-like cheese. Thin ravioli of green-tea dough wrapped around lobster and porcini mushrooms and doused in a warm taleggio cheese sauce came off better, but the soft, floppy half-moons went limp under a pair of chopsticks, like a protester being hauled off by the cops.

Natsumi makes more sense as a bar. As a restaurant dish, that pizza's crazy mashup of mango, fris√©e, raw fish, caviar, mayonnaise and balsamic vinegar reads like a glitch in an online translation program. But after a few Zentinis it's as satisfying as a giant plate of nachos. Maybe Japanese-Italian cuisine just needs a little help from Mexico.
